awd_titl_txt: The School Gardeners' Southwest Desert Almanac:  A Conference for Supporting, Sustaining, and Spreading Garden-Based Science Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
Garden-based science teaching (GBST) integrates formal and informal learning, provides teaching opportunities in a wide range of science topics (e.g., soil science, ecology, botany), and creates a place for those topics to be locally and culturally relevant. A proliferation of school gardens nationwide reveals a significant increase (42%) in the creation of school gardens between 2013-2015 (USDA, 2015). As students increasingly engage in science learning in school gardens, the demand for high-quality instruction also grows. However, much of the available research on school gardens emphasizes health and nutrition interventions, without also characterizing the instructional practices of science. This conference addresses the need for research on effective instructional methods that can be used to support students' science learning in school gardens. The conference will focus on the Southwest Desert ecoregion. The ecoregion focus is driven by the longstanding challenges of coordinating a national model of GBST across ecoregion differences, by concentrating on states and sites whose problems and opportunities reflect common ecoregion conditions. This conference will lead to development of an ecoregional model for GBST that builds on regional ecological and cultural resources to engage teachers and students in richer and more relevant science learning experiences. 

This conference will organize and implement collaborative activities during and after a 2-1/2 day meeting in Arizona. It will involve 35 participants comprised of teachers (grades K-5), teacher educators, educational researchers, and science content specialists who collectively bring experience with science teaching in school gardens, culturally relevant pedagogy, traditional agricultural practices, and science practices. Conference activities will draw upon participatory design research methods to understand how, when, and why educational innovations work in practice. A key product of the conference and post-conference activities will be an ecoregion model of GBST as instantiated by The School Gardeners' Southwest Desert Almanac. The Almanac will be an online resource for information on GBST, collaboratively produced by practitioners and researchers during- and post-conference activity. This website will feature curated resources such as a multi-media set of case studies illustrating GBST instructional practices.

The Discovery Research PreK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As the number of gardens on school campuses continues to increase (USDA, 2019), the demand for high-quality garden-based instruction also grows. In this project, researchers and educators shared individual perspectives and built collective insights that support and advance garden-based science teaching (GBST). GBST integrates formal and informal learning, provides teaching opportunities in a wide range of science topics (e.g., soil science, ecology, botany), and creates a place for those topics to be locally and culturally relevant.

Our collective work yielded two main findings. First, developing GBST resources involves designing instructional content that is sensitive to local contexts. Garden environments embed disciplinary topics ​​(e.g., soil science, ecology, botany) in the unique conditions of a particular place and often as a reflection of the regional customs of a community. Second, sharing GBST resources involves not only well-designed instructional materials but also the repertoire of practices that educators enact as they facilitate learning linked to local places and peoples, past and present. These paired findings have been shared in several different ways.

Conference participants collaborated with the investigators to co-author 2 white papers, 8 online multi-media case studies, a poster and interactive session at a national conference, and 2 peer-reviewed journal articles. All of these resources are also consolidated at the project website: https://www.schoolgardenalmanac.org/ and summarized below.

The white papers engage the extant literature on garden-based science teaching in relation to the conference topics (i.e., place-based learning, culturally responsive pedagogy, design, and science teaching) in order to present opportunities for ecoregional approaches to research, teaching, and learning. 

The case studies present practitioner perspectives on garden-based science teaching in relation to the conference topics. Each case is organized as a narrative supported by video illustrations and the instructional materials used by the authors.

The conference poster and hands-on session were presented at the North American Environmental Education Association. The poster invited attendees to explore and discuss the role that design plays in understanding and improving garden-based science teaching. The session shared, demonstrated, and discussed four of the conference case studies.

Separate peer review journal articles target practitioner and researcher audiences. An article in Science & Children provides an in-depth presentation of one of the eight case studies developed by conference participants. An article in Environmental Education Research demonstrates the value of design-based research for making progress on garden-based science teaching and environmental education in general.

Lastly, while the finalized version of the project website (https://www.schoolgardenalmanac.org/) will showcase all conference deliverables through 2024, an archive of the website will also remain accessible at https://archive.org/web/ after 2024.
